abstract.para: Kernel Control Groups (cgroups) are a kernel feature that allows assigning and limiting hardware resources for processes. Processes can also be organized in a hierarchical tree structure.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: Every process is assigned exactly one cgroups. cgroups are ordered in a hierarchical tree structure. Resource limitations can be set for single processes or for whole branches of the hierarchy tree. Limitations for CPU, memory, disk I/O, or network bandwidth usage can be set.
On &productname;, &systemd; uses cgroups to organize all processes in groups, which &systemd; calls slices. &systemd; also provides an interface for setting cgroup properties.
The command systemd-cgls displays the hierarchy tree.
This chapter is an overview. For more details, refer to the listed references.

note.title: Unified Control Group Hierarchy
note.para: This setting is available only if the unified control group hierarchy is used, and disables MemoryLimit=. To enable the unified control group hierarchy, append systemd.unified_cgroup_hierarchy=1 as a kernel command line parameter to the &grub; boot loader. When set to strict, only access to devices that are listed in DeviceAllow is allowed. closed additionally allows access to standard pseudo devices including /dev/null, /dev/zero, /dev/full, /dev/random, and /dev/urandom. auto allows access to all devices if no specific rule is defined in DeviceAllow. auto is the default setting.
